name: Cornell Tech
place_description:
I moved from California to NYC to pursue a Master's in Information Systems, conc. in urban tech at Cornell Tech.

Here, I get to work on interdisciplinary projects that deepen my understanding of emerging technologies and GIS. Toggle to projects in the side panel for a taste!

I spent my early twenties in Berkeley. I earned a B.A. in Data Science and Economics from the University of California, Berkeley.

Living in the long shadow of Silicon Valley shaped my understanding of how the world works and who runs it.

Still, the sun hits different in California.

I was a project manager at Microfinance at Berkeley, a small business consulting club at UC Berkeley. I helped two small business redesign their web experience. Working closely with the owners, our team redesigned and prototyped the full booking experience, aligning it with the café’s brand and business goals. Check out our work for Cafenated, a local cafe in Berkeley: Figma prototype
Upon graduating from UC Berkeley, I began my career as a product analyst at an insurance firm, where I worked for two years.

name: IntelliBART
place_description:
While I never lived in San Francisco, the city left a lasting impression on me. During the pandemic years, I observed how a city built around tech can leave other industries and institutions by the wayside.

Be that as it may, it was here that I first explored public transit data, with much of my early work focused on the Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) system.
Mumbai is where my parents live, so it is the closest to a home. I completed my high school years here!
I got to work on a cool taxonomy project when I was a research asssitant at UC Berkeley's Essig Museum of Entomology. A couple years later, I visited Oahu and Maui with some friends.

My parents and I lived in Yokohama for two years. I remember riding on the local subways and bullet trains with my mom. Looking back, this is probably where my predilection for public transit first began.

After Japan, my parents and I moved to Singapore. It's a small country, so I know it's hard to compare to places like the U.S. or India, but it showed me what's possible when a city is thoughtfully planned.

After Singapore, my parents and I moved to Sydney—a different ballgame altogether. The car-centric lifestyle was a bit tough for my mom and me, since we were used to walking everywhere. It felt isolating after living in such pedestrian-friendly cities, but it was also one of the most beautiful places I've ever seen.

name: ESRI UC 2025
place_description: I was selected as a student assistant for ESRI's User Conference, one of the world's largest GIS conferences, held in San Diego, California.

name: ESRI Summit 2025
place_description: I was selected as a student assistant for ESRI's Developer & Technology Summit in Palm Springs, California. I really enjoyed Palm Springs!

As a product analyst for an insurance firm, I was responsible for Personal Lines Auto and Property insurance for Arizona, Nevada, and Utah. While I never got to visit these states, I did get to work on some cool projects that helped me understand the ins and outs of the insurance industry.

As a product analyst for an insurance firm, I was responsible for Personal Lines Auto and Property insurance for Arizona, Nevada, and Utah. While I never got to visit these states, I did get to work on some cool projects that helped me understand the ins and outs of the insurance industry.

As a product analyst for an insurance firm, I was responsible for Personal Lines Auto and Property insurance for Arizona, Nevada, and Utah. While I never got to visit these states, I did get to work on some cool projects that helped me understand the ins and outs of the insurance industry.
My office was in Walnut Creek when I worked as a product analyst at an insurance firm.

Some Urban Tech students and I investigated smart city initiatives in West Hollywood, including smart buses, nodes, and streetlights, and proposed a post-pandemic plan to sustain and expand them. Here's a presentation we made.

As part of my HCI & Design coursework, I collaborated with a team of MS students to design a new e-commerce website for the soon-to-launch Café Aviva on Roosevelt Island. We spoke with the owner, Alon Kruvi, to understand his goals, aesthetic preferences, and the atmosphere he envisioned for the café. Next, we created a high-fidelity prototype in Figma that reflects his brand’s style and layout. Take a look at the prototype!.

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for BK11 community district. Check out my research paper!

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data (Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints. This map presents the results of that analysis for BK17 community district. Check out my research paper!

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for BX5 community district. Check out my research paper!

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for MN10 community district. Check out my research paper!

I identified optimal tree planting locations using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map presents the results of that analysis for QN2 community district. Check out my research paper!

name: Extreme Heat Mitigation
place_description: I identified optimal tree planting locations in the five boroughs of NYC using land surface temperature data from Sentinel EO Hub's Landsat 8 LIDAR (shown in red) and Michael Treglia's 'practical canopy' framework, which considers land use, cover, and infrastructure constraints (shown in green). This map shows the two metrics across NYC. Check out my research paper!

I got to visit New Zealand with my parents. I really loved this country. It is fascinating how they rebuilt Christchurch after the 2011 earthquake. Look at the video I shot of Border Collie and Hunt Away dogs herding sheep in Agrodome, Rotorua in the North Island!

name: The New York Trilogy
place_description: My interest in GIS, cartography, and AR/VR culminates in The New York Trilogy, which is composed of NYC Eats, NYC Races, and NYC Screens!

name: NYC Eats
place_description: NYC Eats, part of the New York Trilogy, is a web map of all restaurants participating in the biannual New York Restaurant Week.

name: Text Me Not
place_description: Fun web app that analyzes your Whatsapp texts with friends or partners to detect patterns and insights in your communication. Check it out at here!

name: NYC Screens
place_description: Proof-of-concept web app that helps users find indie movie screenings and films shot in NYC, the mecca of cinema, using Figma and AR/VR techniques. Check out the prototype here!
